sn11.1:2.1: The gods (deva) stem from Proto Indo-European dyew, “shining, sky, heavens” (cf. Pali diva, “day”; English “day”, however, is a false friend), while the titans (asura) are the negative form of Proto Indo-European sóh₂wl̥, “sun”, so asura is “sunless, night”. As the day vanquishes the dark of night each dawn, the gods defeat the titans. Victory is sweet but short-lived, for soon follows dusk, at which the titans prevail and plunge the world into darkness once more (Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 1.2.5.1, Taittirīya Brāhmaṇa 3.2.9.7). Note: The Vedas know the sense of asura as (human) “lord”; but given that the opposition between deva and asura is known to the Avesta, I assume that is the older sense and the sense “lord” derivative; cf. English “titan of industry”.
sn11.1:2.5: Sakka himself is accused of negligence by Moggallāna at MN 37:11.2. Sakka or Indra is a heroic deity associated with the accomplishment of great deeds, and accordingly here he extols energy. | As a historical curio, in the earliest mention of Sanskrit pramāda (Rig Veda 8.2.18), it is the “exhilaration” from drinking Soma which grants the gods led by Indra unsleeping tirelessness. This passage lends support to the idea that Soma was originally a stimulant, perhaps ephedra. Nonetheless, pamāda became associated with drunkenness and hence “negligence”.
sn11.1:4.4: Disa is imperative of disati (“show”) in the sense “render, bestow, confer”.
sn11.1:7.2: The Chinese texts at both SA2 43 (活) and SA 1114 (生) appears to support jīvati rather than jīyati. Bingenheimer at SA2 43 has, “Have you ever seen or heard of someone who, without effort, attains happiness in life?” Both Chinese texts have more lines than the Pali; given that the Pali has five lines, it seems likely the text has suffered loss. I translate according to what I guess the meaning to have been.
sn11.1:8.2: This is a tricky construction. The idiom idha kho taṁ, bhikkhave, sobhetha occurs several times, always in the same context: someone is said to have some quality, and the mendicants are encouraged to have it even more so. The preceding clause usually includes hi nāma, suggesting a dependent clause (SN 11.2:8.2, SN 11.4:13.2, SN 35.103:5.7, Kd 16:6.4.2, Kd 5:4.3.1). Sobhetha is second plural optative in the sense “you all can (out)shine or excel”.
